body: It would cause me a lot of problems if this was the default - the current behavior disallows things that work in es3 but break in es5+. Allowing these things with ecma’s version 3 would produce code that can *only ever* work in pre-es5 engines. What’s the usefulness of that?

@ljharb AFAIK, the default language version is ES5 (in case you missed it, I specified `"ecmaVersion": 3` in the configuration). Does this address your concern, or do you think that when the `ecmaVersion` is 3 the parser should only accept code that is valid in **all** ECMAScript versions from 3 upwards?

No, it doesn’t. I explicitly set an ecmaVersion of 3 on 300+ of my npm packages, all of which must work in both es3 browsers and newer ones, and all of which use strict mode.

What is the value of allowing code in ES3 engines that will be guaranteed to break on all newer engines?

@ljharb It's all about correctness. Strict mode was introduced with ES5. Pre-ES5 browsers do not honor strict mode. On the other hand, if I had to forbid certain constructs that are not allowed in strict mode while still keeping ES3 compatibility, I'd rather use rules for that (e.g. [no-octal](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-octal), [no-with](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-with), etc.) that setting `ecmaVersion` to 3. I did not consider the problem of compatibility with existing ESLint configurations, so this would be a breaking change.

If you want sloppy mode semantics, then you wouldn’t include the strict pragma. By including it, you’re already writing es5+ code.

It could be done with an option, but the question remains: why is that useful? Sloppy mode semantics are *bad* and to be avoided anyways, and if you need them, you wouldn’t use the pragma.

Are you deploying code to IE 6, and *not* to any ES5 engines? I’d love to understand that use case.

@ljharb Well, if it interests you, I was playing around with some JavaScript compilers written in Java (you know, GraalVM and the Closure Compiler) and I was using ESLint to check my expectations, until I stumbled upon this strange thing with strict mode in ES3. I think of it as an aberration, but the behavior could be intentional as well. I just could not find any bugs or discussions about this topic, so I thought I would open a new issue.

I agree there's some philosophical interest in being able to lint ES3 code and ignore the strict pragma, but as I stated above, I don't think there's any use in that being by default. It could certainly be done via an option, if the eslint folks wanted to maintain that complexity.

Because this is a parsing error and not a linting error, that means it’s coming from Acorn and not ESLint. I’d suggest opening up an issue on Acorn to see what their response is. They usually have a good reason for seemingly incorrect behavior like this that may not be obvious, and if not, they’ll know the best approach to address it.

issue.title: SyntaxError for invalid strict mode syntax with ecmaVersion 3

repository.name: acorn
repository.description: A small, fast, JavaScript-based JavaScript parser

body: This was indeed an issue in acorn. It seems to be fixed now: https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/commit/353e24f72bd4b8d4cba3755498bdc862540b4659. Thanks @nzakas!
Awesome. I'm going to reopen because we need to take this into account when we integrate Acorn.
